information: A series of polls conducted between March and June 2025 show Andrew Cuomo as the frontrunner in the Democratic primary. A SurveyUSA poll in May showed Cuomo as the first choice for 43% of likely Democratic voters, with Zohran Mamdani at 11%. A Marist poll from early May placed Cuomo at 37% and Mamdani at 18%, and a simulation showed Cuomo surpassing the 50% threshold to win in the fifth round of ranked-choice voting. An Emerson College/PIX11/The Hill poll from late May placed Cuomo at 39% to Mamdani's 23%. Earlier polls from March by Honan Strategy Group and Data for Progress also showed Cuomo leading Mamdani with 41% to 18% and 39% to 15%, respectively.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: ~15 days until the June 24, 2025 primary; a presumptive call likely within 0–7 days after, depending on RCV tabulation and absentee ballots.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — Cuomo maintains his polling lead and becomes the presumptive Democratic nominee after RCV rounds.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Progressive consolidation and high activist turnout power Zohran Mamdani past Cuomo in late RCV rounds; or a late-breaking scandal/negative story depresses Cuomo’s vote/transfer share enough for him to lose. A sizable polling error concentrated among younger and left-leaning voters could also flip the race.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Cuomo converts his broad name recognition and dominant first-choice lead into an RCV majority by mid-to-late rounds, with enough second-choice transfers from moderate/establishment-leaning candidates to clear 50%. Credible outlets call him the presumptive nominee within days of the primary.
forecast.rationale: Weighting the status quo heavily: Multiple independent polls from March–late May show Andrew Cuomo consistently ahead by mid-to-high single digits to high teens on first-choice vote share. The assistant’s summary cites: SurveyUSA (May) Cuomo 43% vs. Mamdani 11%; Marist (early May) 37–18 with an RCV simulation showing Cuomo surpassing 50% in the 5th round; Emerson/PIX11/The Hill (late May) 39–23; earlier March polls also had Cuomo near 40 with Mamdani in the mid-teens. The trend suggests Mamdani has been gaining, but Cuomo retains a clear lead with two weeks to go. In NYC Democratic primaries with RCV, a candidate sitting near 40% with broad name ID and resources is typically favored to reach a majority after transfers, particularly if moderates and establishment-leaning voters cluster around him and minor candidates’ voters split their backups. Reasons the forecast is not higher: 1) Recent momentum appears to favor Mamdani (narrowing margins). 2) RCV introduces transfer risk for a polarizing figure; Cuomo’s negatives could limit second-choice inflows, allowing a progressive consolidation to overtake him late. 3) NYC primaries can be low-turnout and skew younger/activist in some districts, increasing volatility and the chance of polling error. 4) Late-breaking news or endorsements (e.g., key unions, The New York Times, progressive groups) could shift second-choice dynamics. Reasons the forecast is not lower: 1) Cuomo’s sustained lead across multiple pollsters and time points. 2) A Marist RCV simulation explicitly showed him reaching 50% by round five. 3) Only ~2 weeks remain, limiting time for a full-scale realignment. 4) Cuomo’s resource and name-recognition advantages should help stabilize his floor. What would move me up: New high-quality polls in mid-June showing Cuomo at or above ~40% with stable/favorable favorables, or credible RCV analyses indicating he collects sufficient transfers from minor/moderate candidates; major establishment endorsements consolidating behind him; early vote/turnout patterns skewing older/moderate. What would move me down: Polls tightening to within single digits on first-choice, or showing Mamdani with a clear advantage in second-choice transfers; major negative revelations about Cuomo; a cascade of progressive and union endorsements to Mamdani; signs of unusually high youth/left turnout. I note resolution depends on a presumptive call; while RCV/absentee counting can delay calls by several days, that does not materially change the underlying win probability at this time.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Andrew Cuomo win the 2025 Democratic primary for New York City mayor?

Question background:
[Cuomo’s lead narrows as Mamdani gains ground in NYC mayoral race: poll](https://pix11.com/news/politics/cuomos-lead-narrows-as-mamdani-gains-ground-in-nyc-mayor-race/)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Andrew Cuomo is the presumptive Democratic nominee for Mayor of New York City after the primary is held on June 24, 2025, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).

If by the end of this tournament's scoring no presumptive nominee has been called (for example because there are not yet conclusive results from the vote counting), this question will be annulled.


Your research assistant's report says:
A series of polls conducted between March and June 2025 show Andrew Cuomo as the frontrunner in the Democratic primary. A SurveyUSA poll in May showed Cuomo as the first choice for 43% of likely Democratic voters, with Zohran Mamdani at 11%. A Marist poll from early May placed Cuomo at 37% and Mamdani at 18%, and a simulation showed Cuomo surpassing the 50% threshold to win in the fifth round of ranked-choice voting. An Emerson College/PIX11/The Hill poll from late May placed Cuomo at 39% to Mamdani's 23%. Earlier polls from March by Honan Strategy Group and Data for Progress also showed Cuomo leading Mamdani with 41% to 18% and 39% to 15%, respectively.

Today is 2025-06-09.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
